item.title: Final Fantasy XIV Might Not Be On PS4 Forever, Yoshi-P Says
item.content:encoded:
Final Fantasy XIV producer Yoshi-P has declared that while he wants to keep supporting the MMORPG on PS4 for "as long as possible", technical limitations might mean the game drops support for the platform eventually.

In an interview with Feed4Gamers, Yoshi-P says that his "basic stance" is to continue supporting hardware "which has grown old", but that Sony's "hardware regulations" might make it difficult for Final Fantasy XIV to remain on the last-gen console.

According to Yoshi-P, the game's continuous updates mean that Square Enix has been asking Sony to increase its data limits for Final Fantasy XIV specifically, and while Sony has been happy to oblige, the company has told Yoshi-P and his team that "they are also reaching their limits", he says.

Yoshi-P says that his goal is to keep Final Fantasy XIV on as many platforms as possible for as long as he can, but that eventually, last-gen hardware will reach "its limits in terms of its technology".

However, when that time comes, Yoshi-P promises that he will "provide clear reasoning for that decision", so if and when PS4 support does end for Final Fantasy XIV, you'll know about it.

This discussion comes after a couple of prominent games recently ended support for the PS4; earlier this month, HoYoverse declared that PS4 support for gacha RPG Genshin Impact will end next year, and PUBG publisher Krafton subsequently followed suit for its battle royale shooter.

In both cases, the studios said they wanted to focus on current-gen hardware for their games, and that's something for which Yoshi-P seems grateful too; in the aforementioned interview, he says current-gen hardware is "quite high spec" and that working with it is "easier...compared to back in the days".

This interview comes shortly after the release of Patch 7.3 for Final Fantasy XIV, which brought a brand new story dungeon, the second part of the Final Fantasy XI-themed 24-person raid, and more earlier this month.

You can check out Final Fantasy XIV right now on PC, PlayStation, and Xbox Series X|S. A mobile version of the game is also in development.

item.title: Long-Delayed Replaced Now Due in Spring 2026, Sad Cat Studios Reveals
item.content:encoded:
Replaced developer Sad Cat Studios has revealed that work on the game is still very much underway, and that it's now due to launch sometime in spring next year.

In a new development update, project lead Yura Zhdanovich acknowledges that Replaced has "seen a couple of delays", but he says that he and his team have always "been trying to do what's best for the project".

Zhdanovich says that he and Sad Cat Studios are "really close to finishing production" on Replaced, and that the next phase is "intense testing and polishing of the game", although he doesn't say exactly how long he expects that phase to take.

To tide you over until spring, Zhdanovich reveals that Sad Cat has "improved every aspect of the game" since it was initially revealed back in 2021. He says the team's goal was to make the game with "no shortcuts", and so everything has been made "in a classic way", with "handcrafted pixel art".

The rest of the trailer delves into Replaced's animation and development processes. It's worth a look if you're interested in the story behind the game, and you can check it out here courtesy of IGN.

If you're not familiar with Replaced, it's an upcoming action platformer that blends chunky 2.5D-style pixel art with gameplay that "combines cinematic platforming...and free-flow action combat".

Set in an alternative 1980s, Replaced casts you as an artificial intelligence known as R.E.A.C.H., who's trapped inside a human body. You'll have to adjust to life as a human, all while discovering that "everything comes at a price", according to Sad Cat.

When it does finally arrive, Replaced is set to launch on PC via Steam, as well as on Xbox Series X|S, and it'll be a day one Game Pass title as well. A specific release date will be announced later this year.
